The Eastern Telegraph Company, Limited.
div.p:
This Company's system of submarine telegraph
cables is the most direct and quickest means of
communication from Egypt to Europe, North and
South America, East, South and West Africa,
India, Australia, New Zealand, China and Japan.

To secure quick transmission, telegrams should
be marked Via Eastern.

For latest average time to London, see daily
bulletin in this paper.

div.head: Peninsular and Oriental S. N. Company.
div.p: Summer Rates will be charged from 2 May to 31 October.

For the convenience of families and others, a large portion of each ship’s accommodation has been reserved for Egypt, so that Berths can be definitely engaged at once, as if the voyage were commencing at Port Said. Plans can be seen at the Offices of the Company’s Agents.

The through Steamers for Marseilles and London are intended to leave Port Said after the arrival of the 11 a.m. train from Cairo, every Tuesday for the present except the MONGOLIA, which is taking passengers to the Anglo-French Naval Review, and will not wait at Port-Said on 24/25 July. A steam tender will meet the train to convey passengers to the ship.
The Brindisi Express Steamers leave Port Said directly the Indian Mails arrive. Passengers can go on board the evening before. The Fare remains as usual.
For all further information apply to the Company's Agents,
Messrs. THOS. COOK & SON (Egypt) Ltd. CAIRO.
GEORGE ROYLE, Esq. PORT-SAID.
Messrs. HABELDEN & Co. ALEXANDRIA.

div.head: KHEDIVIAL MAIL LINE.
div.p: Express Steamers leave Alexandria every Wednesday at 4 p.m. for PIRAEUS, SMYRNA, MITYLENE, and CONSTANTINOPLE, in connection with Orient Express train-de-luxe for Vienna, Paris, and London.

Fast steamers leave Alexandria every Saturday at 6 p.m., and Port Said every Sunday at 6 p.m., for JAFFA (for Jerusalem), CAIFFA (for Nazareth), BEYROUT (for Damascus), TRIPOLI, ALEXANDRETTA, MESSINA, continuing in alternate weeks to LARNACA and LIMASSOL (Cyprus).

Steamers leave Suez weekly on Wednesday at 6 p.m. for Port Sudan and Suakin direct returning from Suakin every Wednesday noon. Every Monday at 6 p.m. a steamer leaves Sues for Jeddah continuing every other week to Suakin, Massowah, Hodeidah, Adem. Intermediate steamers do not proceed beyond Jeddah but call at Tor, (for Sinsi) el Wedj and Yambo as required.
N.B.—Deck chairs provided for the use of passengers, excellent cuisine and table wine free.
Steamer plans may be seen and passages booked at the Company’s Agencies at Alexandria, Cairo, Port Said, and Suez, or at THOS. COOK & SON or other Tourist Agency.

div.head: Icilma.
div.p: ARABIC FOR "FLOWS THE WATER.”

Icilma Fluor Cream is the only cream that contains no grease nor oil. Deliciously scented it cleanses the pores of the skin as nothing else can do, makes it pearly white, gives life to the tissues, elasticity to the muscles, and a deliciously cool feeling to the skin.

Its unique properties are due to Icilma Natural Water so that it may well be called Nature’s Skin Food and the skin requires nothing else to give it the necessary vitality, to preserve it from sunburn, heat, cold or the effects of hard water, to prevent and cure the minor irritations due to overheated blood, and to preserve the youthful fresh look to which hot climates are so fatal.
Invaluable for immediately curing mosquito and insect bites and for greatly preventing them.
Depot for Egypt : J. McGregor, Chemist.
Alexandria, Cairo, Ibrahimieh, Luxor, Icilma Co. Ltd., 142, Gray’s Inn Road, London, W. C.

div.head: AVIS
div.p: La Municipalité met en adjudication les travaux de prolongement de la rue des Parcs au sud de l'ancien cimetière israélite jusqu’au fort el Nahas.
Le cautionnement est fixé à LE. 15.
Le cahier des charges est déposé an Bureau de la Voirie où il peut-être consulté par les intéressés tous les jours de 9 h. à midi, les jours fériés exceptés.
Les offres devront être adressées sous pli cacheté à Monsieur l'Administrateur de la Municipalité avant le 18 courant.
Elles pourront également être déposées en séance de la Délégation la même jour à 5h.p.m.
L’enveloppe devra porter en outre la mention: “Soumission pour les travaux de prolongement de la rue des Parcs.”

Le cautionnement ou le reçu d’une banque, d’après les conditions du cahier des charges, devra être remis séparément au Service de la Comptabilité Générale avant l'ouverture des offres et au plus tard le 18 courant à midi.
Toute offre qui ne remplit pas les conditions ci-dessus sera écartée.
L'Administrateur.
(signé) W.P. Chataway.
Alexandrie, le 7 juillet 1905.

FRIDAY, OCTOBER 26, 1906

div.head: A MORAL FOR ENGLAND
div.p: A MORAL FOR ENGLAND

Mr. J.L. Garvin contributes to the “Outlook” a thoughtful study apropos of the centenary of Jena. “Modern research and reflection,” he writes, “hav e dispelled the ordinary legend of Jena, and the. true moral of that battle is probably more useful to the English people at this moment than to Germans themselves. It w as not caused only—it was not caused mainly

the Frederician military system or by absolute inefficiency of the Prussian army. No. Chastise] ment was visited upon the accumulated faults of an optimistic nation and a procrastinating Government. The campaign was lost before it began, and Prussia was enslaved, dismembered, and temporarily destroyed as a GreatbPower chiefly as the result of neglect and stagnation in domestic policy—especially respecting military and social reform—and by a policy of indecision, hardly distinguishable from perfidy, in foreign affairs. Unlike the ruthless realist who had expired twenty years before, Frederick William the Third was through and through a self-deceiver. . . . Willing to seize the territory of any neighbour wherever it could safely be done, he was a genuine, though a weak, philanthropist in the abstract, passionately devoted to the ideal of peace, desirous of getting more territory without fighting for it, and covering a policy of considerable dishonour by the self-excusing casuistry of a pietistic sentimentalism. . , . Austerlitz was fought. Austiian and Russian were crushed. The retreating Tsar Alexander concluded no formal peace, but left sixty thousand Russian troops encamped in Germany and at the disposal of Prussia. . . . England had offered Frederick William large subsidies if he should be driven to extremity. He was placed in the strongest possible position for negotiation by the diplomacy of London and St. Petersburg, and he resolved to negotiate exclusively in his own interests. Napoleon played for' time with consummate policy. He knew the interior nature of the Prussian conscience and offered— Hanover. That electorate belonged to an intimately friendly sovereign, the King of England. To occupy it would make Prussia tho ally and accomplice of tho Cassar, and would be an act of cynical duplicity unprecedented oven in the diplomacy of that time. But tho prize was splendid, and Frederick William’s over-scrupulous conscionce assured him on reflection that the proceeding was legitimate. Hanover was seized ; and Buonaparte’s wicked knowledge of self-deceiving human nature was triumphant. Austria had been forced to make peace by Prussia’s desertion. England was driven tp declare war against Prussian aggression. The Tsar’s contingent was dismissed from Prussian soil by Prussian ineptitude. Frederick William even disbanded the greater part of his own army now that he had obtained Hanover. Then—then—when he stood stripped of dignity and power, a doomed figure clutching plunder .... Napoleon offered Hanover to England. Modern history knows no such touch of Satanic irony. Frederick William committed the supreme folly. Having failed to act with Austria and Russia the year before, he now determined with his isolated and unready forces to challenge his overwhelming opponent .... The moral Jena had preceded the memorable campaign now to open.” After tracing the military drama in swift outlines,' Mr. Garvin concludes:—“The blow fell upon Prussia when the need of military reconstruct tion had been widely recoghised and in the midst of hesitating inclinations towards half- and-half reforms. The army was commanded by superannuated officers who ought to have been removed because they had served under Frederick the Great. For a number of years a far-kighted minority had passionately pressed for the introduction of universal service, for the creation of a great national reserve. The king, like Mr. Haldane, was half- convincd. Yet numbers of patriotic Prussians, foreseeing the ultimate danger, had clearly understood and explained Napoleon’s methods. All were unheeded. And why was effective reform postponed some chief reasons appear. Prussia enjoyed unusual prosperity. Comfort had never been so widely diffused. The air _ was full of a vague Liberalism. Optimistic sentimentalism prevailed. Budgets were framed upon the principles of economy at any price. Worst of all, the fact that in the period before Jena a genuine belief in the approach of universal peace was widely held, and proposals for European disarmament wero mooted. . . The Prussian army of 1806 was beaten by Latin genius; its successor might be beaten by Latin genius again. But behind it stands tho inexhaustible réserve of the'nation in arms . .

The overwhelming probabilities are that Germany will not be permanently confined to her present limits ; that her furthest reaching ambitions, nevertheless, will be powerfully and finally checked; but that she «ill not uguin go down in a day, nor without honour, nor without a struggle which will convulse the Continent before another disastrous sunset sinks upon the ascendency of her arms.
Pilgrims at Suez.
A special landing stage is to be built at Suez for the embarkation and disembarkation of pilgrims
The Brindisi Mall.
The mail for Europe, via Port Said and Brindisi, will close at the G. P. 0., Alexandria, at 8.30 a.m. on Sunday.
Sudan Industrial Schools.
The Sudan Government intends to establish an industrial school at Omdurman and at Earsala. A third is contemplated at El Obeid, Eordofan.
The Opera Season.
The repertoire of the Italian opera company which is to give performances at the Abbas Theatre, Cairo, next season will include Arnica and Macbeth.
Jardin Francais.
A gala performance will be given on Saturday for the debut of Libre et Change, which could not take place on Wednesday owing to the rain.
Weights and Measures.
Captain Moore, the active officer of the Port Said police, has seized a quantity of false weights and measures which he found in various shops. Proceedings will ensue.
H. M. S. Terrible.
The cruiser Terrible left Port Said early yesterday morning for Malta, where she will go into dry dock for the repair of her broken propeller.
Egyptian University.
Dr. Eloui Pasha has promised a subscription of L E. 1,000 for the establishment of an Egyptian University on condition that it will observe strict religions neutrality.
Land Seal.
The Egyptian Land and General Trust, Limited, has purchased the Souaya estate from the Comptoir Franoo-Egyptien, consisting of 45 000 square pics, at the price of P.T. 160
per pic
Inniskllllng Dragoon’s Reconnaissance.
The Inniskilling Dragoons passed through Abou-Eebir yesterday morning en route to Simbellawein, accompanied by an inspector cf the Ministry of the Interior.
Church of Scotland, Cairo.
The morning and evening services of St. Andrew’s Church of Scotland, Cairo, have now been resumed, the hours of service being 10.-30 a.m. and 6 p.m.
Collape of a Shed
A shed attached to the engineering workshops belonging to Messrs. Easter, in the Souk el Ghanem, collapsed yesterday, probably in consequence of the heavy rains. Fortunate ly no one was injured.
Hisratic Papyrl.

The Royal Museum of Berlin has just issued part 9 of volume. of its ‘collection of Hieratic Papyri. The manuscripts given are from Elephantine, and many are as old as the 6'h dynasty, so competing in point of antiquity with those discovered by Dr. Petrie at Guru.
Native Appeal Court,

Ali Eff. Z ice El-Arabi, Mohamed Eff. Abon el Eheir, Tonnis Eff. Salih, advocates of Cairo; Ahmed Eff. Tewfik, Tantah; Emile Eff. Rati, Benin Sonnet, and Tewfik Eft. Doss, Assioot, have been anthorised to practice as advocates before the Native Court of Appeal.
Dynamite Explosion.

Some natives employed in blasting in the Ehalifj quarter of Cairo had a narrow escape yesterday from the stones displaced by the explosion of a dynamite cartridge. One, indeed, was struck on the head, and had to be removed to hospital suffering from severe oonooesion and loss of blood.
Suez Canal.

On the 24th October, 11 vessels, of which 4 were northward and 7 southward bound, transited the canal, and pufor transit and passenger toll Fr. 320,948.28. The total receipts since October 1 are Fr. 6,634,298.94, and during that time 213 vessels transited the Canal, 107 being northward, and 136 southward bound.
Highway Robbery.

Last week a cotton grower of Mehallet- Eobra, in Gharbieh province, was attacked by highwaymen, who, after stabbing him, robbed him of his earnings. He was afterwards able to identify his aggressors, who are now in custody. Not so long ago, a headless corpse was found in the same neighborhood_— the grim trophy of murder.
The Poet Offloo Forgery Caee.

The ease of Ibrahim Ragi, who, in collaboration with the proprietor of *'AI Umma,” forged a signature in order to obtain a money order from the Cairo Post Office, will come before the Cairo Criminal Court on the 6th it at. The accused has not yet been arrested, despite the efforts of the polioe, hot will nevertheless be tried and sentenced inessential.
Egyptian Mummy Tickets.

Mr. H,R. Hall, of the British Museum .whose Corpus of Mommy Tickets in that collection was published by the Society of Biblical Archaeology last year, has just, edited for the Museum Trustees the "Series of Coptio and Greek Tex'." of the Christian Period” from ostraoa, stelæ and other monuments. The work is illustrated by 100 plates, and is of great interest to all parsons studying early Egyptian Christianity.

div.head: CAN EGYPT GOVERN ITSELF?
PROOF TO THE CONTRARY
div.p: One of the stock theories ot the native Press is that, inasmuch as Egypt is capable of self- government, therefore jt should be endowed with representative institutions. This forms the theme of countless leaded articles in the columns of our vernacular contemporaries, and "A1 Moayad” and "A1 Lewa” are tireless in calling upon England to redeem her pledges and forthwith begin to endow this country with parliamentary government of the European type.

fiat instead of the natives becoming more capable of self-government we see that the reverse is the case, for as Egypt progresses the Government finds (hat it is more and more necessary to increase the number of European officials without a corresponding increase in the native staff.

A striking example of this is evidenced in recent appointments to the Ministry of Finance. Last year an eminent English financial authority was appointed from outside to the important post of Director of the Treasury. A few months afterwards it was found obligatory to increase the English high officials in this Ministry by appointing a second Under-Sere- tarry of State, and now the Government intends to make use of the great experience of Chhay Bey and to transfer him from thé director-generalship of the Customs Administration to an important newly created post in the same Ministry.

All these gentlemen have been appointed to these high positions because, in the opinion of the Government, there is not a single native capable of fulfilling such duties, despite the fact that wo have been trying to educate the Egyptians to govern themselves for over twenty years. Moreover, it is not only in the highest ranks that this spectacle is seen, for now every year batches of Oxonians and Cantabs are selected to fill the lower administrative posts, evidently beoanse the younger generation of natives, in spite of their having been ednoated under British superintendence, are incapable of filling these positions.
No Progress Made.

As Mr. Edward Dicey wrote in 1902 : "I cannot see that we have made mneh progress as yet towards the avowed object of our policy, as propounded in Lord Dufferin’s report, namely, that of reorganizing the administration of Egypt on enlightened ideas, so as to render the country capable of governing itself in accordance with these ideas supposing our troops should be withdrawn. What progress has been made towards this end seems to me of the oral order—backwards. Our theory of teaching Egypt how to govern herself by enabling her to enjoy the advantages of just, honest and progressive administration under. British control, however sincerely the theory was conceived, and however loyally it has been carried ont, was based on a delusion. England has indeed succeeded in establishing a system of administration in Egypt, which is an enormous improvement upon any Government the country has ever known, but this systems depends for its vitality noon its being carried oat ly British officials. It the work was left in the hands of native officials not subject to British authority, [the old abases of all. Oriental governments would revive at once I Tutelage is an excellent system for administering the affairs of persons incompetent to manage by themselves : but this system does not tend to render the persons under tutelage competent administrators.”

The longer therefore that England remains in Egypt, the less and less- capable will Egyptians become of self-government and, that this is the oase is seen in the greater number of appointments of Englishmen to official positions in Egypt, especially in the instance of the Finance Ministry, which we gave above, where after all these years new And highly-paid posts have to before- ted which no Egyptian is competent to fill. It is an inevitable consequence of the existing state of things, for as the power of the State grows the energy of the individual must dwindle. As a relent observer said : "If ever the activity of the State should extend through and through to every department of life, the universal ease and comfort which may be thins disseminated throughout society will have been purchased dearly at tube price of the son. The denizens of that State will be fed, housed, aid loathed to perfection : only--and it is a serions drawback— they will be dead." This is a tendency of all modern civilized, states and especially so is it the oase with modern Egypt, where the Government is all in all. It is useless for our native contemporaries therefore to talk about self-government, for, as Mr. Dioey says, any progress îd that direction in Egypt has been of the crab order—backwards.

div.p: Medical visit with disinfection and dératisation is declared against arrivals at Constantinople from Adalia and Fort Said.

div.head: STEAMER MOVEMENTS
div.p: The Fiorio-Rubattino S.S. Perseo, due at Alexandria on Sunday, left Naples six hours behind time, owing to a shore porters’ strike at Naples. Weather. Permitting, however, she should reach here at 3 p.m. on Sunday.
The Messageries steamer Niger arrived at Marseilles from Alexandria on Yesterday morning.
The Moss liner Menes arrived this morning from Liverpool, v & Gibraltar, Algiers, and Malta, with passengers, mails and general

The S.8. Scottish Prince lift Malta ye-ter day for Manchester with passengers) and general cargo.

div.head: NEW CAIRO OPERA HOUSE. FOUNDATIONS BEGUN.
div.p: Preparations for the destruction of the Eebekieh Gardens, and, incidentally, the deprival of Cairo oi one of its now too few longs, for the purpose of building a new opera ko usa, are proceeding apace. M. Santi, proprietor of the garden restaurant, has received notice Bo quit on the 1st of February and the digging of foundations has already commenced.

A contemporary Bates that the selection of the site was decided upon by Sir VifcMnt Corbett, but we can hardly believe that. So, important a matter would surely be decided by a committee, and only after great consideration, especially in view of the fact that the director- general of the Public Health Department expressed his strong disapproval of the site now selected. Unfortunately, the public health of Egypt receives far too scant attention, as has been well evidenced in Alexandria why the disease-pregnant odours which have been disease-pregnancy amours warren nave Dean,
caused in almost every district of the town to close

div.head: EPIDEMIC OF DENGUE
div.p: There have been a considerable number of oases bf dengue at Cairo lately, and we hear that a perfect epidemic of this unpleasant complaint is raging at French and Assouan. It is suggested that the recent appearance of mosquitoes—till lately almost unknown at Assouan—may explain the increase oi dangle at the latter locality.

div.head: THE KHEDIVE
div.p: The Khedive arrived at Ras-el-Tin Palace from Montasah at 10 o’clock this morning, and attended midday prayers at Abonsinn Mosque.
His Highness will grant a private audience to Lord Cromer this afternoon.

div.head: LORD CROMER.
div.p: Lord Cromer arrived at Alexandria from Cairo at 1 p.m. to-day, and was met Ut the station by Mr. E. B. Gould. I.S.0, H.B.M.’a Consul-General, and Hopkinson Bey, Commandant of Police. His lordship linked at the British Consultant afterwards proceeded to Ras-el-Tin Palace, where he was received in private audience by the Khedive. He will return to Cairo by the afternoon express.
Lord Cromer paid a visit to the Governor of Cairo on Wednesday afternoon.

div.head: MINISTRY OF JUSTICE
div.p: The rumour is current that Ismail Pasha Sabri, Under-Secretary of State to the Ministry of Justice, is about to resign, and that he will be replaced by Saleh Pasha Sabet, president of the Native Court of Appeal, to which post Judge Bond would probably succeed. Other papers categorically contradict this news.

div.head: HAIFA-AKABA RAILWAY.
div.p: "A1 Abram” is informed by a recent arrival from Dama8ons that the Turkish Government has prepared plans for a new branch of the Ottoman Railways, to run from Haifa to Akaba, passing through Wadi-el-Arab.

div.head: REFORM IN EGYPT
div.p: It is said that next week will see important revelations concerning the ruffian with which Lord Cromer and the Advisers have been so busily occupied since hit lordship’s return.

div.head: THE ARABIC DRAMA
div.p: In an interesting article contributed to the "Moayed,” a critic dispones the suggestion made by several Arabic littérateurs that it is time for the Arab theatre to give Arabic dramas instead of translations of the chqf-dœuvres of European playwrights.

The writer, in reply, points oat theft while the theatre of Sheikh Salama El HegazI is well managed and supplied with excellent scenery and accessories, the Arab companies have not yet the prestige of European players, nor are they yet capable of interpreting the more subtle character studies of the greatest dramatists. As kings, conspirators, faithful friends, and passionate lovers, they succeed and will in time, no doubt, essay more complex rôles with success. Meantime the Arab theatre is- still young. Its development man come sooner or later, but there is no reason to hurry on the composition of native dramas till both the literary and the dramatic capacity, necessary to do justice to them, have reached a higher stage of development,

div.head: TRAM CAR COLLISION
div.p: As a tram-car was running along Ramleb- boulevard yesterday afternoon it collided with considerable force with a cab which was drawing op at the door of Messrs. Barker and Co.’s office. The cab was split into two pieces, the box being entirely separated from the body. Mr. Cyril Barker, who was seated in the cab, had a very narrow escape of being seriously injured, but be jumped ont of the cab just in time to save himself. Curiously enough, Mr. Barker’s father was knocked down by a carriage is Chief Bakhtaran this morning, but fortunately received no serious Injuries

div.head: SHOPPING IN EGYPT British and Foreign Methods
div.p: (From a Correspondent.)

In England daring the last decade the gentle art of shopping has undergone somewhat of a revolution. A run up to town for a few days for that purpose is no longer essential. Postal facilities and elaborately illustrated catalogues enable the purchaser in the majority of instances do all that is necessary from his or her armchair.

English trades-people are alive to the importance of this branch of their business, and a small order through the post receives the same paroral attention as a larger one over the counter. They are aware that a customer who is satisfied is an advertisement for them, personal experience acquired in the Sudan, to and fuss result is a largely extended trade.
Here in Egypt it goes has not yet dawned, so they have to, rely on fly care and discretion of the firm with which they place their order for their satisfactory selection and dispatch.

There is little doubt that the average Englishman, be he Imperialist or Little Bog- lander, has a natural inclination to place his orders with fellow-countrymen, but when there are foreign competitors in the same branch of trade the longish houses should remember they 'oak ill afford to concede anything in the way of courtesy or attention without seriously endangering their interests. The little homily I only venture to read them had its genesis in an incident which was recently brought to my notice.

A lady residing in the provinces wrote to three Cairo firm, one French wind two English, for patterns and prices oi a material which she was aware they kept in stock. By return of poet He received a courteous letter in excellent English from the French firm, enclosing the patterns required. Two days later one of the English firms sent their patterns in an envelope without any covering note in reply to the question asked. The third firm never even vouchsafed an answer. The material submitted by the French house was superior in quality and cheaper than that of its English competitor,
Question of Credit.

Borne time ago the Writer had occasion to order a suit of clothes from an English firm in Cairo. It was the firta-eader-ef that nature be bad given them. He requested that the suit, when finished, should be forwarded to a provincial town, giving at the same tim9 his Cairo address. The suit was duly forwarded contre remboursement, and he refused to accept delivery of the parcel. On writing the firm complaining that it was unreasonable to expect prior payment for a garment of which he had not even an opportunity of seeing in its finished state, he received a polite letter of apology informing him that the parole had beau re-dispatched in the ordinary way. In this letter, the firm stated they had frequently been victimized, not invariably by their fellow- countrymen, and had therefore been obliged to adopt this preliminary measure. The writer had been introduced to the firm by a customer of theirs to whom they allowed a liberal credit. It is «it unreasonable to assume the existence in Egypt of a bureau of information analogs to the Trades Protection Society in England, and in any case, it would not bave been difficult for the firm to have ascertained whether the writer was in the habit of meeting his liabilities.

Incidents anon as the foregoing tend to explain how it is possible tor a London fireproof tailors to send a representative to Egypt each winter to book orders at a moderate price for which a year's credit is allowed.

Again, sums English houses in Egypt exhibit a reprehensible laxity in dealing with their correspondence. A remittance which the writer sent to a firm a week ago in settlement of their account has not, np to date, been acknowledged, although he has received an invoice for goods ordered at the same time.

The writer knows of several instances where English people have diverted theft orders to a French firm. The reason given is that they receive better attention, the goods are more carefully dispatched, fewer rets takes being made m executing the orders and lu the rendering of accounts, and greater pains are taken in procuring from an outside sourer without extra charge, such goods as the firm does not happen to have I stock tor the time being.
lot On Parlo Anglais.

In more than one establishment in Caire it extremely difficult for English people to make their waist understood by the assistants, who, while-professing some knowledge of the language, are insufficiently versed therein to enable them to intelligently interpret customer’s demands. An tempts at French or Italian are, not Infrequently, correspondingly obsonre, enduring a rupture of negotiations pending the arrival on the scene of a gentleman qui parle [Anglais parfaitement.

Should the foregoing remarks meet the rye of any of those responsible for the condoned of English establishments each as I have, in a general way. ventured to criticize, it is not I Passione some improvement may ensue in the direction indicated, bringing a meet of satisfaction to the customer, and, let as hope, a larger measure of prosperity to the houses exonerated.
In ton event the object of the writer will have been attained.

div.head: DRINK IN THE SUDAN. FACTS AND FIGURES.

The article has also a head line calling attention to an "Buorosons Increase.” It seems to me that fur from being aa enormous in ornate, these figures bow a decrease in 1900 on the amount quoted as value in 1904.

give Borne information that will alter materially the unornate that have been or may be drawn from a perusal of the article alluded to, and as this subject will probably elope the attention of both House of Parliament it sometime during the present Session, I trust yon wilt extend the courtesy of your columns the what I have to say in the matter.

The number Of Europeans (who ate the sole consumers of spirituous drinks) résident in the 8ada»rare, ae quoted in the utile, 2,787, but it must be re-embody that «H the beer, wine, and spirite destined for competition in Uganda and the Lado Enclave find their way thither through the Sudan, and consequently form a putt of the imports and- el to in the article.
Those traders who are to 1 have khadi establishing «tame in the Sodas most noun- scarily provide stokes of spirituous drinks fat licensed use. These stocks are far from being already consumed.

div.p: 6. The weight of the liquors imported in 1904 is stated as 561 tons, which is probably connote, but them vary, which is said to be £119,738, baa been tiringly exaggerated. The get a correct estimate of value, it is only necessary to recall a well-known fact, vis., tint liquors go into tile Sudan in oases. Forty tan of wine or spirits go to a ton, and each ease
contains Ig bottle.
Behr to a ton, and each oasis contain 48 bottles. My extended experience tells me that the 561 tons world représentas follows:

tons of whisky of the import
tons of assorted spirits, wines,
tons of champagne.... £2,430
This amount of £17,618 is practically the value of the 561 tons eve spirituous liquors imported in 1904, and not £119,738.

Again, 561 tons of miscellaneous drinking liquors world average about 15,720 eases. These on the assumption that their value was £419,738 would give an avenge all round value of £7.12 per oases, which is absurd.
I beg to enolase my oared, which yon will recognize as bearing a Well-known name in tube Sudan, and remain, Yours very truly,
A Sudan Merchant.
Alexandria, 95th October.

div.head: EDUCATION IN EGYPT. To the Editor of the "Egyptian Gazette"
div.p: Deter Sir, —I your article of yesterday aid to-day on "Egyptian Licentious” your cur- respondent aeon to be under toute miss- apprehension with regard to tire Secondary Schools.

The years in the Safety Schools have not-been reduced from three to ‘two. Ou the Murry, they have been extended from three to four, and no student can to the secondary 'Certificate until he has studied four years in a Secondary School.

The ones of the misapprehension sacre to have been the introduction of a “half-way muri” examination into the middle of tire four sure Roader Course. div.head: THE PLAGUE
div.p: Two admissions of bubonic cases of plague to Alexandria hospital are reported, the first being a Greek boy from an oil ship in the Minet el Bassal quarter, and the second a native boy from the Custom House quarter. Both cases have been isolated since Wednesday

div.head: Circulaire H. De Vries et Boutigny
div.p: NOTES BY CRITIQUES

Le taux de l’escompte libre à Londres est toujours k 5 7/8 pour cent. Hier, au Stock Exchange, le Consolidé anglais est resté invarié à 85 7/8, de même que l’Uflifiée à 104. La National Bank, l’Agricole et les autres valeurs égyptiennes ont également conservé leurs prix de la veille.
A Paris, l’action Crédit Foncier Egyptien a réactionné de 2 francs k 782. La Banque d’Athènes est revenue à 144.

L’amélioration qui s’était dessinée hier sur notre marcné des valeurs s’est vivement accentuée ce matin. Les transactions ont été nombreuses et une plus-value sensible s’est manifestée, au début, sur presque toute la ligne de la cote. A noter qu’un petit tassement, amené par des réalisations, s’est produit, vers le milieu de la séance, sur les titres qui avaient le plus bénéficié du mouvement.

Dans le compartiment des Banques, la National a débuté a 27 3/8 pour finir a 27 3/16- 1/4. L’Agricole a progressé a 9 13/16, acheteurs, pour mollir a 9 3/4-13/16. La Cassa di Seonto a avancé a 243-244 l’action ancienne et 238 la nouvelle. Le Comptoir Financier s’est tenu a 6 15/16-7 l’action ancienne ; l’action nouvelle a gagné 1/16 à 6 3/4.

Le Crédit Foncier est revenu a 782-783. La Daïra s’est raffermie a 16 15/16-17. La Béhéra a encore gagné 1/4 de livre a 40 1/4. La Nile Land a été traitée a 16 3/16-1/4. La part de fondateur Immobilière a passé de 740 a 760. L’Union Foncière a haussé à 6 7/16-1/2.
Les Improvement» ont été fort recherchés et ont clôturé a 6 1/4-5/16; on verra, certes, des prix plus élevés, pleinement motivés d'ailleurs.
Continuant son mouvement ascensionnel, l’AUotment a dépassé un moment le pair pdtar réactionner fortement a 3 13/16; la part de fondateur a atteint 177 pour revenir a 170.
Les Jouissances Eaux du Caire ont avancé a 273. La Frigorifique s'est raffermie à 4 7/8- 15/16. Les Automobiles sont remontées a 6 1/2.

L’action Express Nile a avancé a 3 5,8- 11/16. On a remarqué des achats faits discrètement par des personnes au courant, qui semblent s’être employées a ramasser le peu de flottant existant surplace; on peut d’s lors présager des prix beaucoup plus hauts dans un bref délai.

Le groupe des valeurs hôtelières a été spécialement actif. Les Nungovich ont passé a 18 7/16-1/2, les Egyptian a 7 1/2 et les Upper Egypt a 5 B/8-’l 1/16. Les National se sont consolidés a 4 1/8 ; leu- part de fondateur a progressé a 80. v.__

Il y a un mouvement significatif sur les Excelsior qui, de 3 7/8, ont clôturé a 4 1/16, acheteurs. Cette hausse est, évidemment, le résultat forcé de la plus-value considérable acquise par le terrain de la Société. Il s’agit de 5,500 mètres. carrés environ, dont le prix de revient par mètre est L.E. 22 et qui est évalué aujourd’hui L.E. 38. Ce surcroît d’actif de L.E. 88,000 a son importance, ne fùtrce qu’au point de vue d’un simple . calcul, le nombre total des actions n’étant que de 37,500.

Parmi les petites valeurs, la Delta Land a atteint 3 15/16 pour clôturer a 3 7/8-15/16. Les Estates ont progressé- aux abords de 2 1/4 pour terminer a 3 1/8-3/16. Les Hooaer sont restés a 1 1/8-3/16 ; on rapporte que le Trust vient d’acheter, en participation avec un groupe, un excellent terrain de construction, de 50,000 pics carrés sis a Alexandrie, rue Menasce, pour la somme de L.E. 90,000, soit a P.E. 180 le pic. Les Walaer and Meimarachi ont faibli a 0 5/8-11/16 et les Abdy a 1 1/4-5/16.

CHANNEL TUNNEL SCHEME. Submission of Plans to Governments.
div.p: The directors of the Channel Tunnel Company have resolved immediately to deposit the plans of the tunnel in England and France for the necessary preliminary promotion, next session, of a private bill authorising the scheme. (Reuter)

div.head: NEWFOUNDLAND FISHERIES. Question in Parliament
div.p: House or Commons —Mr. Winston Church- ill, replying to Mr. Ashley, stated that the Newfoundland Government had been consulted with regard to the fisheries agreement before the negotiations began, and were also informed of the progress of each stage. The Imperial Government were, however, not so fortunate as to obtain the Newfoundland Government’s concurrence. (Reuter)

div.head: AUSTRIAN MINISTERIAL CHANGES. Statement by the Premier.
div.p: Chev. von Pitreicb, Minister of War, has resigned. M. Schoemaiob, Austrian Minister of National Defence, succeeds him.

The Austrian Premier stated isthe Reicbs- rath that Count Goluchowski. resigned spontaneously. The Hungarian Government, he said, would in future always exercise its legitimate influence in the international policy. This change would not affect the foreign policy, of which the Triple Alliance will remain the principal foundation. (Reuter)

div.head: RUSSIA AND JAPAN. New Commercial Treaty.
div.p: The Japanese draft of the new commercial treaty with Russia is being considered by the Foreign Office. (Reuter)

div.head: RUSSIAN VISIT TO ENGLAND
div.p: A Russian squadron, including the Slava, Tsarevitch, and Bogatyr, under Admiral Bos from, will arrive to-morrow at Barrow-in- Furness, The officers will visit the Vickers Maxim works, and London, and other places in parties. (Reuter)

div.head: PRINCE HOHENLOHE SUSPENDED.

div.head: NEW ZEALAND.ANTI GAMBLING BILL.

div.head: QUEEN VICTORIA’S BIRTHDAY.
div.p: The Queen’s nineteenth birthday was celebrated amidst general manifestations of the loyalty and affection of all classes. {Reuter)

div.head: SINAI EXPLORATION. Prof. Flinders Petrie's Work
div.p: Professor Petrie tells in the preface to his most recent work how the short stay in the Peninsula in the winter of 1804 5, of which Researches in Sinai” is his own unofficial record, was the fulfilment of a wish cherished for twenty-six years, and the book bears eloquent testimony to the remark that the "surprises” were more important than the duty which prompted the mission. The sculptures and inscriptions of the Wady Magbareh and the valuable archæological remains of the Wady Feiran, Mount Serbal, and the Temple and Mines of Serabit have been visited by other travellers, but none has had Professor Petrie’s advantages of observation or his eminent qualifications for utilising them. The result is the correction of much that was positively held by Egyptologists, and the confirmation of not a little that was previously doubted.

‘The earliest signs in Egypt,” writes the author, “of intercourse with Sinai are the beads of turquoise, rarely found in the prehistoric graves. . . The beginning of the monuments of Sinai is in the First Dynasty, about B.c. 5300. The seventh King of that Dynasty is here (Wady Maghareh) written as Semerkhet. . .. On a smooth natural face of the upper sandstone rock, at 394ft. above the valley floor, the scene of this king has begun engraved by sinking the ground and leaving the figures in relief. . .. The next monument. carved was that of King Sa-nekht, the founder of the Third Dynasty, about b.c. 4950."

Around Maghareh and Serabit Professor Petrie discovered adsorptions relating to thirty- nine Egyptian monarchs, down to those of Setnekht (b.c. 1203-1202) of the Nineteenth Dynasty, a hundred years subsequent to the Exodus, all of whom appear to have worshipped Harbor, or the 1 Mistress of the Turquoise”; or. in other words, to have sent mining expeditions to Sinai. The building of the Temple of Serabit, which the Professor discovered to have ultimately attained 23Gfc. in length, seems to have kept pace with the greed or reverence of these Egyptian kings. Thanks, however, to an English miring company operating in the ancient turquoise mines vast quantities of priceless sculptures and inscriptions have been ignorantly destroyed, and the author is Datn- rally bitter on this vandalism. “Everything,” he writes, "gave way to the greed for dividends, with the result that the promoters lost their money, the natives lost their turquoises, and the world lost many of its most ancient monuments."

But the most remarkable portions of this volume lie in the author’s deductions from his discoveries. There is font fact, or perhaps we should call them theories, which head venire with much confidence. These are : (1) That "common Syrian workmen, who could not command the skill of an Egyptian sculptor, were familiar with writing at B c. 1500, or 6C0 years before the earliest Phoenician writing known j” (2) that "we have here before ns (Temple of Serabit) a Semitic cave shrine, older than th9 Mosaic worship or any ether worship known tons in Syria or Arabia... And We see how Mo9aism was a carrying on of older ritual, how that movement was a monotheistic reformation of existing rites, and how the paganism of the Jews was bat the popular retention of more than was granted in the State religion (3) that the numbers of the Israelites of the Exodus, as given in the Book of Numbers, are shorn of their apparent exaggerations if we read the thousands (alaf) as tents or families, and the hundreds as the number of inhabitants of the tents, and that thus, instead of hundreds of thousands. we obtain the figure of five or six thousand marshalled by Moses in the Wady Feiran to do battle with the Amalekites—the anther showing that this reading is alone oncomes- rate with the life-support capacity of the Sinai Peninsula in those days as in these; and (4) that the chronology of the Egyptian dynasties which he follows in the volume mast be approximately correct—in fact, in Chapter XII. the Revision of Chronology, Professor Petrie speaks not only to the ordinary reader, hut to Egyptologists with a note of complaint that the ground arguments for Egyptian chronology have been so little re-
IIUOU.

“Researches in Sinai” is remarkably exempt from the dry-as-dust style popularly supposed to clog the pens of- desert explorers. The volume is superbly illustrated by nearly two hundred photographs and four maps. The last four chapters, in one of which the writer definitely decides on Gebel Serbal as the Mount of the Law, and suggests that the manna of the wilderness was snow, are contributed by Mr. C. T. Currelly who spent two months with Professor Petrie’s party, and owing to the obduracy of Turkish soldiers at Akabah had to abandon a journey to Petra, and return to Suer by the Nakhl pilgrim route. Professor Petrie’s estimate of the population of the Peninsula probably errs on the side of caution, and possibly does not include the entire country between the Suet Canal and the Wady el Araba. The following passage, however, will explain his inclination towards discrediting the number of twenty or twenty-fire thousand given by other travellers: "My wife asked him, when at our camp, if there was a village up the valley. He replied, ‘Yes.’ ‘And how many people are there 1' ’One,’ said he. This is on a par with a young Bedawy who, from the heights of Serabit, pointed ont four black tints in the far-off
valley, and exclaimed with dignity: ‘Behind
the city (Medineh) of the Aleygat’—his own tribe. which is population in Sinai,”

div.head: ARMY AND NAVY
div.p: (From our Correspondent.)
London, October 16.

The 1st Battalion King’s Own Scottish Borderers, Lieutenant Colonel D. A. Mactar- lane, D.S.O., commanding, will embark at Southampton on the 21st prox. for Alexandria, per the S.S. Dongola. The battalion is due to arrive at Alexandria on the 1st December

The Government having decided to out_ down the Army without obtaining the approval of Parliament, intends, it is stated, to deal in a more drastic way with the Navy. Briefly stated, their scheme is this: Eight first-class battleships and four armoured risers are to be paid off, and eight more first-class battleships are to be removed from the sea-going list before the end of the year. In other words, the naval force which Great Britain will have ready to go to war at the shortest notice will be reduced by twenty capital ships, or about one forth. Font battleships of the Mrjeatio class are to be taken from the Channel Fleet, two from the Atlantic Fleet, and two of the Formidable classism the Mediterranean Fleet. The whole of the Royal Sovereign class is to be placed in the reserve without news. These are not old or Niele ships, for the oldest of them was built in 1892; and, of course, it is not intended to replace them by newer and better ships. The object of the Government is to save money, and enable Mr. Aeqnith to present a poplar Budget. But this reduction of ships is not the only one which the Navy will sustain. The crews who are now at sea in the ships to be discarded will live in barracks, and will lose some of their efficiency. Success in naval battles depends on the efficiency of the officers and men as on the quality of the ships in which they fight. Hitherto the public have had confidence in. the bluejackets, believing them to be as well trained as those of any Navy in existence. The scheme of the Government, if carried out, will destroy this confidence. In a naval war the battleships in the reserve might be commissioned to take the place of those sank or disabled, but sailors drawn from the reserve would not be as efficient as those who were constantly at sea, and they would be placed at a disadvantage in fighting German crews, who are believed to be as well trained aa our own are new. It was generally understood that both parties were agreed that it was absolutely necessary to maintain our naval supremacy, and also that they were agreed about the meaning of the term. It was an accepted doctrine that the British Navy most be able to meet the combined navies of the two strongest Powers, with a good chance of victory. Lord Charles Beresford said; "To make the British Fleet equal in fighting strength to its possible enemies—two other nations—it should be numerically superior at least by one third.” When these sixteen battleships and four armoured risers are thrown away, it will be considerably inferior to the fleets of the two next strongest naval Powers. France and Germany will have 52 battleships against Great Britain’s 39, or a superiority of 13. France and the United States will have a superiority of 6, and Germany and the United States a superiority of 2. It may be said that all these combinations are improbable. We are on good terms with both France aid United States, and neither of these Powers is likely to join Germany in attacking ns. It should be remembered, however, that changes in international polities occur with dramatic suddenness. We cannot afford to allow our existence as a nation to depend on the goodwill of other Powers.

div.head: The "African World"
div.p: SPECIAL EGYPTIAN SUPPLEMENT.

We must congratulate our London weekly contemporary “The African World" on the publication of their last supplement, which is devoted to Egypt, and which reflects infinite credit on editor, publisher, and printer. The comprehensiveness of its literary contents and the representativeness of its numerous and excellent illustrations make it a volume well worthy of addition to the libraries of all who are interested in' Egypt. The limited liability companies of Egypt are dealt with in a concise and simple manner, which cannot fail to be distortive to financier and layman alike, and several of Egypt’s more important commercial interests are referred to in wider detail. Though the majority of articles are devoted to financial and commercial matters, ample space is given to subjects of less serious and important interest, prominent among which is an excellent description of street life in Cairo.

The illustrations, we have said, are both excellent and representative. Among the most instructive of these are a bird’s-eye view oi the Nile valley and a commercial map, the former old which tells one at a glance the positions of the principal towns, villages, and monuments, while the latter gives one a very good idea of the products of the varions districts np to the borderland of the Congo States and British East Africa. The many photographs of the leading lights of Egypt— official, financial, and social—are exceptionally good.

div.head: The Bagdad Railway
div.p: FURTHER DIFFICULTIES ARISE.

Mezel Khan, sheikh of the Persian town and territory of Mchammerah, situated on the frontier of Persia and Asiatic Turkey and complying an important position at the confluence of the Karan and the Shatt-el-Arab, some 25 miles south-east of Basra, has been for some time in active correspondence with Mubarek-es-Saba, sheikh of the independent state of Koweit, in Turkish Arabia.

There are grounds (the Constantinople correspondent of the "Manchester Guardian” says) for attributing to Mezel Khan the design of severing all the ties that bind him to the Court of Teheran and - following the precedent set by Mubarek-es-Saba some years ago, when he broke with the Turks-of proclaiming Mobammerah an independent and autonomous State.

The defection of the Sheikh of Koweit deprived the Sultan of a valuable ally against the desert tribes, and the German promoters of the Bagdad line of the projected terminus at Koweit, which is the finest natural harbour on the Persian Gulf. It has always been understood that behind Sheikh Mubarak was to be found the British Government, and some support is given to this theory by Lord Cutzod’s visit of a few years ago daring his Viceroyalty.

Mobammerah, as will be seen by the map, commands the left hank of the Shatt-el Arab, the great river formed by the iodination of the Tigris and Euphrates, and is strategically fitted to suspend all communication by water between Basra and Bagdad and the sea. Steamers of large burden now ply op the rivers as far as Bagdad.

div.head: Kelway's Manual.
div.p: The fifty-fifth edition of "Kelway's Mannal of Horticulture” (Kelway & Son, LaDgport) shows the progressive improvement of previous issues. It is a reliable and helpful handbook to the purchase and culture of the best plants and seeds for the garden and contains excellent illustrations of a very large number of species of plants. It is a "garden book” in the trine sense, and should be of great interest and vaine to all concerned in horticulture.
